message_1: A physics student is required to calculate the numerical aperture of an optical fiber that has a core refractive index of 1.45 and a cladding refractive index of 1.40. The core diameter is 50 μm and the cladding diameter is 125 μm.
message_2:
The numerical aperture (NA) of an optical fiber is a measure of its light-gathering ability and is related to the refractive indices of the core and cladding. The formula to calculate the numerical aperture is:

NA = √(n_core^2 - n_cladding^2)

where n_core is the refractive index of the core and n_cladding is the refractive index of the cladding.

Given the core refractive index (n_core) is 1.45 and the cladding refractive index (n_cladding) is 1.40, we can plug these values into the formula:

NA = √((1.45)^2 - (1.40)^2)
NA = √(2.1025 - 1.9600)
NA = √(0.1425)

NA ≈ 0.3774

So, the numerical aperture of the optical fiber is approximately 0.3774.
